Harvard Business School was critical we
thought of it as being part of our own
incubator so we took tons of
entrepreneurial classes we worked with
our peers the professors all of the
resources for me the most challenging
part was going through each different
round and knowing that we had a
different bar and the bar kept getting
higher and higher and to be able to sort
of say Okay round one this is it and
then I have the same business and the
same product but I know I can do better
and I'm going to do better for the next
round and NVC was kind of a catalst or
Crucible moment for us to finally arrive
and say you know what yes there's lots
of problems with our business model or
this or that or this can be fixed or
this isn't perfect but I believe this is
going to be a really big business and
we're going to go after it there was no
expect on our part that we were going to
win so it's actually like a super nice
surprise it hasn't really sunken yet and
um more than anything the real work
starts now and that's super exciting so
we're going to work on this fulltime
over the summer and the idea is to get
to scale in Boston we're going to do a
real launch in Boston hopefully you'll
hear about us in Boston Globe maybe New
York Times um and to really try to get
to density and scale because it's all
about making the formula which we can
kind of water and then carry City by
city so I'm really proud to go to
Harvard Business School because I think
that the entrepreneurial scene here is
actually starting to take off and I'm so
grateful to the professors who have been
pushing for it so hard Professor Solomon
and professor eisan and especially the
Rock Center they work so hard to make
this happen and I really appreciate all
the stuff that they do so thank you
